item.title: Snowden Says He Reported N.S.A. Surveillance Concerns Before Leaks
item.description: Edward J. Snowden said that he initially told officials of his concerns about the National Security Agency’s surveillance operations, but that none “took any action.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Censors Hit Delete on a Party Chief’s Censorship Remarks
item.description: It seems that comments on microblogs about Internet censorship, even by senior Communist Party officials, can fall prey to China’s army of online minders.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Zhang Chunxian, Communist Party secretary of Xinjiang, was questioned by reporters on Thursday about the recent stabbing attack in Kunming.

item.title: Common Sense: Why Russia Can’t Afford Another Cold War
item.description: The old Soviet Union was all but impervious to foreign economic or business pressure. But now it has a stock market, and an economy heavily reliant on exports to Europe.
item.category: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation|BK|NYSE
item.dc:creator: By JAMES B. STEWART
item.media:description: A Soviet tank on a street in Budapest. The old Soviet Union was all but impervious to foreign economic or business pressure.

item.title: Ukrainian Officials in East Act to Blunt Pro-Russian Forces
item.description: Arrests and new appointments are likely to increase Kiev’s control and help avert a situation similar to the one taking place in Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riot police officers took a break from guarding an administration building on Friday in Donetsk, Ukraine. The police retook the building from pro-Russian protesters who had seized it.

item.title: Among the Wounded in Syria’s War: Ancient History
item.description: Archaeologists, long kept from their work in Syria, now hear reports of fighting and theft at historical sites and museums.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: A rebel fighter in a devastated alley in Aleppo, Syria, last week.

item.title: For First Time, Kremlin Signals It Is Prepared to Annex Crimea
item.description: Leaders of both houses of Russia’s Parliament said that they would support a vote by Crimeans to break away from Ukraine, ignoring sanctions threats and warnings from the U.S. and other countries.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS, DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Turkey’s Leaders Spar Over Plan to Muzzle Social Media
item.description: President Abdullah Gul said he would not go along with a pledge to shut down Facebook and YouTube by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who is facing a corruption inquiry.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: "We won't allow the people to be devoured by YouTube, Facebook or others," Turkey's prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, said in a television interview on Thursday.

item.title: As Kerry Visits Jordan, Abbas Holds His Ground
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry made an unannounced visit to consult King Abdullah II even as the Palestinian president restated positions that underscored the challenge Mr. Kerry faces.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: World Briefing: French Court Convicts 3 Who Tried to Join Militants in Syria
item.description: The three men were arrested in 2012 as they were boarding a flight to a Turkish airport not far from Syria and charged with criminal association with the intent to commit terrorist acts.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Fact-Finding Envoys in Crimea Face Hostility
item.description: An envoy from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said she faced threatening crowds in Crimea, similar to the hostility that confronted a senior United Nations envoy.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Astrid Thors is the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe's high commissioner for national minorities.

item.title: Congolese Militia Leader Convicted in Attack on Village
item.description: The militia leader, Germain Katanga, was found guilty at the International Criminal Court of complicity in organizing an attack in 2003 that left more than 200 people dead.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: Germain Katanga, the Congolese warlord, is seen on the television screens in the press room of the International Criminal Court during his trial in The Hague, Netherlands on Friday.

item.title: Court Upholds Ruling Against Ryanair
item.description: A British court upheld an order that Ryanair sell most of its stake in Aer Lingus, agreeing with regulators’ earlier findings.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: World Briefing: More Money Needed to Avert Disaster in Central African Republic, U.N. Warns
item.description: Relief agencies are acutely short of funds needed to prevent more carnage and deaths from hunger and disease, said the United Nations chief aid coordinator, Valerie Amos.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: At War Blog: Building Bridges Between the Military and Universities
item.description: Historically, the relationship between universities and the military has been complicated, though it wasn’t always so tense.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID F. EISLER

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: March 7
item.description: Women working at a brick kiln in Amritsar, Punjab.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Women working at a brick kiln on the outskirts of Amritsar, Punjab, on the eve of International Women's Day.

item.title: Malaysia Opposition Leader Sentenced in Sodomy Case
item.description: An appeals court gave Anwar Ibrahim a five-year term a week before he was expected to register for elections.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Malaysia's opposition leader, Anwar Ibrahim, met his supporters as he left the court building in Putrajaya, outside Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Friday.

item.title: Talk: The Guardian’s Alan Rusbridger: ‘It’s Essential to Be Paranoid’
item.description: The newspaper editor on Edward Snowden, the piano and patriotism.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: Interview by AMY CHOZICK
item.media:credit: Jude Edginton/Redux, for The New York Times

item.title: Off the Charts: New Cold War Would Differ From Old
item.description: Unlike the Soviet Union, today’s Russia has substantial trade ties with Western Europe, and it and the West are more dependent on each other than they were in decades past.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD NORRIS

item.title: Ukraine Won’t Boycott Paralympics in Russia
item.description: Ukraine said on Friday that it would compete in the Paralympics instead of withdrawing in protest of Russia’s intervention in the Crimean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By BEN SHPIGEL

item.title: India Ink: A Rare Government Success Story for Women’s Empowerment in Kerala
item.description: From a few thousand women, the Kudumbashree program in the southwestern state of Kerala has grown into a giant community enterprise with 3.7 million members.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: A Kudumbashree worker involved in community farming near the Kerala village of Kadakkanad. Around 260,000 workers currently till and harvest more than 60,000 acres throughout the state.

item.title: Congo Warlord's Conviction Brings Relief to International Court
item.description: Congolese warlord Germain Katanga was convicted on Friday of being an accessory to war crimes including murder and pillage - only the second conviction in the 12-year history of the International Criminal Court in The Hague.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Detain Government Employee in Beating of Nurse
item.description: The police in Nanjing have detained a government employee after a video of the beating of a nurse generated widespread outrage online.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: India Ink: In Kolkata, Reminders of Why We Help the ‘Last Girl’
item.description: To the women’s rights activists Ruchira Gupta and Gloria Steinem, the bright, hopeful youths from the red-light district illustrate the need to follow Gandhi’s standard of making a difference in the life of the weakest.
item.dc:creator: By RUCHIRA GUPTA
item.media:description: The women's rights activist Gloria Steinem, third from right, with students in front of the Victoria Memorial in Kolkata.

item.title: Malaysian Opposition Leader Is Sentenced
item.description: Malaysia’s state news agency says an appeals court has found opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim guilty on sodomy charges, overturning his earlier acquittal.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Lens Blog: Venezuela in Black-and-White
item.description: Though famed for chromatic installations, Carlos Cruz-Diez was first taken by the magic of light as a young photographer documenting Venezuela’s emergence as a modern state.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: Los Diablos de Yare. San Francisco de Yare, Estado Miranda, Venezuela. 1951.
